The 'Bosniaks', or less commonly 'Bosniacs', Bosniac is the spelling
used in the Oxford English Dictionary ( ; singular masculine: BoÅ¡njak,
feminine: BoÅ¡njakinja) are a South Slavic ethnic group living mainly in
Bosnia and Herzegovina along with a native minority present in other
countries of the Balkan Peninsula; especially in the SandÅ¾ak region of
Serbia and Montenegro (where Bosniaks form a regional majority), and in
Croatia. Bosniaks are typically characterized by their historic tie to the
Bosnian historical region, traditional adherence to Islam since the 15th and
16th centuries, common culture and Bosnian language. In the English-speaking
world, Bosniaks are also frequently referred to as Bosnian Muslims Since the dissolution of Yugoslavia, Bosniak has replaced
Muslim as an official ethnic term in part to avoid confusion with the
religious term Muslim â an adherent of Islam.  or simply [[Bosnians]], http://www.onislam.net/english/news/europe/454802-bosnia-
muslims-integrity-model-for-europe.html though the latter is generally
used to denote all inhabitants of Bosnia and Herzegovina regardless of
ethnic origin.
